titleStmt.title: M109 [The Reader: At what point in Elizabethan drama...]. Typescript, fragment, with the author's ms. corrections, unsigned and undated. 9p.
titleStmt.author: Virginia Woolf

publicationStmt.authority: The Estate of Virginia Woolf, administered by the Society of Authors

msIdentifier.repository: Henry W. and Albert A. Berg Collection of English and American Literature

physDesc.p: M109 [The Reader: But under the ceiling, on the seats, there were gentlemen...]. Typescript, fragment, with the author's ms. corrections, unsigned and undated. 9p.
Numbered 26-27, 31, 34-35. Page 30 filed as p. 178 verso in her Between the Acts, later typescript with ms. fragment.
On fol. 1 verso: [The moment and other essays. Mrs Thrale] typescript
On verso of p. 26-27: [Between the Acts] manuscript fragment

handNote.p: Holograph writing by the documents' main hand, Virginia Woolf

correction.p: Apparent errors have been explicitly corrected in sic / corr tags, wrapped in a choice element.

interpretation.p: Names and references to places and literary works have been wrapped in rs tags which link to annotations and secondary material.

projectDesc.p: Text encoded as part of 'The Digital "Anon": A Digital Genetic Edition of Virginia Woolf's Final Essays'. This project, funded by Leverhulme Grant ECF-2022-602, seeks to construct a TEI-XML based digital edition of the drafts of 'Anon' and 'The Reader', among the final documents Woolf wrote before her death.

div.p:
At what point in Elizabethan (E) drama
a is the reader born?
at what point does one
come to be aware of their
[shape?] in the play: of the
presence of the audience: of the
that of paper drawing up
the past; & become
in a room reading alone?
With of course. He It was
Shakespeare (Sh) who created the reader.
And changed liter

It was her (h ) marriage however that brought about her
peculiar relationship with . Had she been happy,
she would never have known him as she did. It was through
him that she got what denied -- stimulus, society,
an outlet for her irrepressible curiosity and ambition.
But the friendship (freindship) between the old man and the young wife
went far deeper (depper) than allowed the world to guess.
Johnson was not merely a distinguished (distingusihed) guest at the dinner
table. He had the run of the (th) house. He knew the (th) dark passages
and the cupboards with their skeletons. Mrs Thrale told him
all her troubles. She turned to him when Queeney snubbed her;
when Mr Txxxxxx Thrale took another mistress; when ruin threatened (threatned)
them; when one after another the children fell ill, and
died. "What shall I do? What can I do? has th flattery
of my mxmxmxmxmmxmmmxxxmmx friends (freinds) made me too proud of my own

But under the ceiling (celing), on the seats, there were gentlemen,
and noblemen, men versed in Latin and Greek; scholars,
courtiers, statesmen. Their silence was equally profound.
But their influence was also effective. ThxmxBaconsxxmxmx
and found what suited them too
in the playhouse (plyhouse)

for ever weaving nets and threading mazes must (mist) relax them
themselves (slves). The must have players to divert her.
With all his craft and caution he himself embodies (emdoies) substantiates (substantias)
his meditations, gives them a body, a name a shape.
"Nay, retire men cannot, when they would: neither (neihter) will they
when it were Reason: But are impatient of privateness
even in Age and Sicknesse, which require the [Shadow?] (Sa dow):
Like old Townsmen (Townemen) that will still be sitting at their strete
d or door, those who thereby they offer Age (Agge) to Scorn."
Even the [crowd?] pressure of great thoughts (tho ts) issue in a concrete shape.
These short meditations were themselves (themslves) making it possible
for the dramatist to [illeg.] impart them where they seemed
inappropriate (i appropitae). For Everything when times are absorbent (abobrent) yields
some savour to the stew. The irresponsible (i responsible) mountebanks (mountbanks),
clothed in their invisible (invisble) garment of anonymity were
Gos spies, in the streets, also at Court.
If at or at , one of them caught sight
of that grave inscrutable (inscrutbale) figure, he could quickly (uickly) add
him to the (t) list of characters. And hyperbole, though the
groundlings (gr ndl gs) lusted for (fot) it, required correction. Bacon
despising (despsing) the (th) theatre (thetre) for its hyperbole was held (hel) contempt for the stage was (w) medicinal. He was teaching them
to speak slowly, closely, subtly: to stiffen their
poetry with prose: A great age is like youth in the (th)
individual. Any hint is heard. Any voice takes effect (effcet).
Criticism, a grave man (an) frowning (frwoning) in his corner of the royal
box is drawn into affecting the current. And so, as the (th) seasons pass,
the aristocratic contempt severs (sevres) to restrain; The crabbed (cabbbed)
prose of Bacon is seized and transformed (transfomred). The plays are

The great house that deplored (delpored) becomes solid and
entire in the pages of Lady diary.
From the first she is aware of her rights of a noble. She is aware from her first youth of her rights as a
land owner. She has a profound sense of the
the rights of the possessor (possesor). The body is visible to her.
what she [illeg.], the [illeg.]She is for ever rebuilding castles,
acquiring land, asserting her rights to property,
claiming diamond buttons, making inventories (inventroies) of her possessions (possesin)
as if to solidify (soldify) them further. Family love is in part the desire to maintain her [honour?] She has asense of the
family who will inherit (imherit) her possessions.
She sends for her grandchildren (grandcholdren) in order that they (ghey) may
taste the delight of possession (posseson) and so refresh her own satis
faction. The living body is robed in black and yellow
taffeta. Clothes are so important (imp rtant) that they become things
to be handed on. The living body is robed in
black and yellow taffeta. The dead body is sealed in lead
to preserve its flesh from decay (d cay). The The sense of the
body permeates her pages; whether alive or dead.
The human soul seems to become more expressive when its
carcass (carcase) flashed in the public eye. All movements of the human
body, from place to place, are attended with great effort;
and become spectacular (specatacular). Six bay horses drag the coach;
The (Th) coach is lined with green cloth, and laced
with green and black silk lace. Crowds (Crwods) attend (attned) her.
She is for ever asserting her identity,
with initials (inittails) carved in stone even over farmhouse (farm hous) walls.
This is her property; this land is hers by right.
Fxmxmxmxmxmmxmx Certain (Certian) flesh and blood--txmxmmxmxmxmx

due to her

Kings presence, for her

div.p:
much sharper. As these faculties became atrophied,
he became more conscious of the suggestions and
associations of words. Txxxs One word written in Elizabethan (Elizabathn)
spelling bxmxmxmxmx xxxx has suggestions that give it
almost another meaning. It suggests other manners, other
clothes; the difference between one society and another.
Then as reading becomes a universal habit, readers split
off into many varieties. There are the specialised readers,
whose power of drawing (darwing) out the meaning of words is
tremendously developed; so that they remain attached to certain (certn)
aspects of the printed wxxdxx page--the scholars, the
students. At the opposite end of the scale, there is the
very large class of perfectly literate people whose eyes
travel over miles of print yearly, yet never read a word.
Some way where between the two, The reader at the present moment exxxxxsx is placed somewhere
between these two extremes. And his faculty is a very
curious (curous) one. He has the power to make houses and
places, men and women and their thoughts and emotions
visible (isible) to him, from marks on a piece of paper.

Somewhere (Somehwere) between the two comes the reader. His faculty is a
very curious one. He has the power to make houses and places
visible from marks on a piece (ipiece) of paper; to draw emotions (emitons)
of every (very) kind; and also some quality that is independent
of emotion; form; unity. He is capable of all the
impulses of a writer; but lacks the power of creation.
His influence (influnece) upon what is written (wr tten) at any time is
immense; In times of public stress, for instance, the writer
is incapable (uincapable) of writing (swriting); in part at least because
he has no audience. The life of a reader is thus

Thus the life of a reader is bound
up in the life of the book. a xxxx constantly merging is to some extent the life of the book.

It was to satisfy this unshaled blind infant,
stretching (s retching) out his hands and covering his eyes in the Eliza
bethan playhouse that the owe (oew) the Elizabethans novels.
or that very curious book
a half born book; a book that is still amorphous
neither (neother) one thing nor the other (othet); a book that cannot walk;
and yet now and then like an unwieldy (unwildy) child gambols and
breaks the ornaments (ornmanets). But while lived,
the novel was always turning into the play. The reader
was too weak to make his influence felt.
